thread.title: Election 2016: Chris Christie slams ‘weakling’ Obama for foreign policy failures
thread.title_full: Election 2016: Chris Christie slams ‘weakling’ Obama for foreign policy failures - POLITICO

author: Jack Shafer
title: Election 2016: Chris Christie slams ‘weakling’ Obama for foreign policy failures
text:
Chris Christie pledged a stronger, more assertive foreign policy than that of the current "weakling in the White House," the Republican presidential candidate said Monday, adding that Russia's military presence in Syria "is the fundamental failure" of President Barack Obama's foreign policy. "Because he thinks if you do nothing, you can't get in trouble. That's what he thinks," the New Jersey governor and Republican presidential candidate said in an interview with MSNBC's "Morning Joe" in which he addressed the president's "60 Minutes" interview that aired Sunday night on CBS.
Asked how he would handle the situation with the Russian military in Syria, Christie said that he would first institute a no-fly zone. His first phone call, he said, would be to Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"And I'd say to him, 'Listen. We're enforcing this no-fly zone, and I mean we're enforcing it. Against anyone. Including you. So don't try me. Don't. Try me. 'Cause I'll do it.'"
Putin would keep his planes on the ground, co-host Joe Scarborough said.
"You bet he would," Christie responded, adding that Obama got "pushed around" during an interview aired Sunday night with "60 Minutes" correspondent Steve Kroft, who he said "has basically been his buddy during the last seven years."
Christie, whose campaign has remained steady in spite of low poll numbers nationally and in early voting states, reiterated that there is a long way to go until the first voters head to the polls in Iowa and New Hampshire early next year.
“We’re in October. We just are finishing week 5 of the NFL season. We’ve got to go through the entire regular season, all of the playoffs except for the Super Bowl before Iowa votes and we’ve got to go through the Super Bowl before New Hampshire votes. Are we really worried now about whether someone’s 3-2 or 2-3?" he asked. "You know, bet on talent. Bet on the people who have been tested."
“No one on that stage has been more tested than me ," he added.
